comments.body: I'm of the opinion that the actual type of `React.Fragment` should be opaque to clients. The fact that it is a `symbol | number` is an implementation detail. As @tkrotoff suggested I would feel better about changing references to an alias like `type FragmentType = symbol & 0xeacb;`
Unfortunately, our type aliases aren't opaque. So creating something like `type FragmentType = symbol | 0xeacb;` wouldn't be visible by clients anyway.

All I'm saying is this test shouldn't be testing that `React.Fragment` is a `symbol | number`, because that's liable to change. Something like

```ts
const fragmentType: React.FragmentType = React.Fragment
```

would be appropriate.
A type like `symbol & 0xeacb` prevents users from making a mistake by passing a `number` into `createElement`.

```suggestion
interface AttributeProps {
```

`React.Attributes` is not meant to be used that way since it includes props that you never see inside your component or need to validate with `propTypes`. It's technically only a private type.

The test is broken without `extends React.Attributes` -- `WeakValidationMap<AttributeProps>` doesn't have any properties in common with `WeakValidationMap<RefAttributes<RefComponent>>` from `ForwardRefExoticComponent<RefAttributes<RefComponent>>`

Does that mean the test is broken or the new propTypes property in ForwardRefExoticComponent is wrong? I suppose I could say

```ts
const ForwardingRefComponentPropTypes: React.WeakValidationMap<React.RefAttributes<RefComponent>> = {};
```

in the test instead.
I don't know React that well, I'm just trying to get it unblocked for other contributors, so any advice you have is helpful.
Well lets merge this if this blocks other work. I'll take  look later why we need this.

Thanks. I merged it.

@rpokorny Maybe you can take another look too?

> If children is null or undefined, this method will return null or undefined rather than an array.

https://reactjs.org/docs/react-api.html#reactchildrenmap

@alloy Could you take a look at these changes and tell me if I'm missing something? It seems to me that `never` is a more appropriate type for these two cases. The components would reject `ref` anyway. It would never assign `undefined` anyway. The instance would always be `null`.
Yeah that seems fine to meâ€“I used `undefined` simply to match the upstream Flow documentation.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +461,465 @@type ClassComponentAsRef = React.ElementRef<typeof RefComponent>; // $ExpectType RefComponent
type FunctionComponentWithoutPropsAsRef = React.ElementRef<typeof RefCarryingComponent>; // $ExpectType never
type FunctionComponentWithPropsAsRef = React.ElementRef<typeof FunctionComponent>; // $ExpectType never
type HTMLIntrinsicAsRef = React.ElementRef<'div'>; // $ExpectType HTMLDivElement
type SVGIntrinsicAsRef = React.ElementRef<'svg'>; // $ExpectType SVGSVGElement
